newsitem.title: CANADA: Alberta natgas liquids pipeline plots expansion.
newsitem.headline: Alberta natgas liquids pipeline plots expansion.

text.p: The three Canadian companies that own Alberta's pipeline for transporting ethane, a key petrochemical feedstock, said on Wednesday they were considering an expansion of the system which would be in service by 1999.
The move follows a series of recent announcements regarding new plants and expansions in the province's petrochemical industry.

Partners in the Alberta Ethane Gathering System, led by operator Amoco Corp unit Amoco Canada Petroleum Co Ltd, said an open season for shippers to nominate for equal access on the system would be held from April 29 to June 13.

"Expanding the pipeline and opening it up to new shippers will create growth opportunities in the ethane market and support Alberta's growing petrochemical industry," said Don Moe, Amoco Canada's manager of natural gas liquids supply acquisition, said in a statement.
Other partners in AEGS are Alberta Energy Co Ltd and NOVA Corp unit NOVA Chemicals Ltd. The partnership is called Alberta Ethane Development Co Ltd.
AEGS, designed to transport ethane to Alberta markets from the province's extraction plants, consists of three segments of pipeline.
One begins at the Empress, Alberta natural gas liquids extraction complex and another starts in the Waterton area of southern Alberta.
The two join at Joffre in central Alberta, site of planned new plants and expansions announced last week by NOVA, Amoco and Union Carbide.

These segments also connect with a northern leg which will move ethane to Fort Saskatchewan, near Edmonton, for delivery to petrochemical plants and the Cochin Pipeline, which moves natural gas liquids to eastern Canada.
